toxins.name: Sesquiterpene lactones, Pyrethrins
toxins.description: Natural insecticides that cause gastrointestinal and neurological signs.

symptoms.name: Vomiting
symptoms.onset: Not explicitly specified in the sources.
symptoms.notes:
Pom flowers are very popular in indoor floral arrangements, making accidental ingestion common. Carnations are a specific type of pom flower known to cause these symptoms12.
2. Diarrhea

symptoms.name: Diarrhea
symptoms.onset: Not explicitly specified in the sources.
symptoms.notes:
This occurs alongside vomiting as part of a general, mild gastrointestinal upset caused by ingesting the flowers1.
3. Dermatological Symptoms

symptoms.name: Dermatological symptoms (such as skin irritation)
symptoms.onset: Not explicitly specified in the sources.
symptoms.notes: While gastrointestinal symptoms are the primary reaction to ingestion, dermatological symptoms will sometimes appear upon exposure

treatments.name: Veterinary Assessment and Poison Control Guidance
treatments.description: Contact your veterinarian or an animal poison control center immediately for tailored advice based on the amount ingested3. The vet will assess the cat's symptoms and determine if an in-clinic visit is necessary.
treatments.notes:
You should call the vet right away and not wait for clinical signs of poisoning (like throwing up or diarrhea) to develop3.
2. Symptomatic and Supportive Care for Gastrointestinal Upset

treatments.name: Antiemetic and Antidiarrheal Therapy
treatments.description: To manage the gastrointestinal distress caused by the flowers, the veterinarian may administer antiemetics to stop the vomiting and antidiarrheals to resolve the diarrhea. They will also typically recommend feeding the cat a bland diet while the stomach heals
treatments.notes:
Because the toxicity of Pom Flowers is considered mild1, most cats will recover fully within 24 to 48 hours with basic supportive care. However, cats with underlying or pre-existing gastrointestinal diseases may require a longer course of treatment2.
3. Dermatological Care

treatments.name: Symptomatic Skin Treatment
treatments.description: If the cat develops skin irritation from contact with the plant, the vet may recommend wiping, washing, or treating the affected skin to soothe the irritation.
treatments.notes:
Ingestion or exposure to Pom Flowers can sometimes cause dermatological symptoms alongside stomach upset, so the vet will need to monitor and treat the skin if an allergic or irritant reaction appears1.
4. Environmental Decontamination

treatments.name: Removal of the Plant Source
treatments.description: Completely removing the Pom Flowers from the home or moving them to a location the cat absolutely cannot access
treatments.notes: While this is an at-home step rather than a clinical medical procedure, veterinarians emphasize that removing the plant source is a necessary part of the treatment plan to prevent the cat from re-ingesting the flowers and prolonging the illness
